It is suitably referenced, and all major points have appropriate inline citations. --> |B-Class-1=n <!-- 2. It reasonably covers the topic, and does not contain major omissions or inaccuracies. --> |B-Class-2=yes <!-- 3. It has a defined structure, including a lead section and one or more sections of content. --> |B-Class-3=yes <!-- 4. It is free from major grammatical errors. --> |B-Class-4=yes <!-- 5. It contains appropriate supporting materials, such as an infobox, images, or diagrams. --> |B-Class-5=yes |British=yes |Aviation-task-force=yes}}
::There is a WikiCommons image of an Atlas [[Image:Armstrong_Whitworth_Atlas_I_-_Dec_1929.jpgâ€Ž]] which might well be worth including, but which raises a couple of questions. (i) Why the triangle well as the fuselage roundel; is that a squadron marking? (ii) The serial appears (it is not quite clear) to be K1836, but that doesn't match Atlas serials as given by Topper in his Putnam book since he has a gap between K1602 and K2514. This last serial was the first of the trainers and the image is certainly not of one of them. Could it be K1536, an Army Co-Op machine? Maybe the answer to (i) would lead to that of (ii).[[User:TSRL|TSRL]] ([[User talk:TSRL|talk]]) 18:14, 14 January 2009 (UTC)
